text: Not least because the aura of the author supports the marketability of the written commodity, and that applies just as much to 'radical' writing as any other (even to me). Even in an era where anonymous memes are some of the finest literature to be found.

And yet so much of the ideology of literature predates this period, let alone being adequate to c21 forms of meditation, in which some of these discoveries become all too obvious if one care to think writing materially, structurally, historically, technically, etc.

These were all discoveries of the era of mass print, the paperback age, whose 'mechanical reproduction' really did materially revolutionize reading, and really only in the postwar period. 'Theory' has a material, historical infrastructure.

(btw this is how you can tell good autofiction: it'll know that the 'auto', the self, is made up, and opaque to itself, but that the 'fiction' won't be able to escape the gravity of desire, discourse, ideology, without a helluva struggle. It's a rare form & little understood.)

A lot of these discoveries are forgotten, or honored in the breach. Writers don't like to imagine we're just laborers within the word factory, although the soviet productivists thought that might be a good idea.

It's a seizing of the means of production at the level of language, as a prefiguration of the communization of everything else. But since the work of language is mostly ideological, there's agency in the transformation of what is appropriated.
My favorite death of the author is at the hands of détournement: writing by copying, but then also correcting. Which the situationists took from Lautréamont, in the interests of literary communism.

The author died bc we killed 'him.' Him in that the author is treated, like God the Father, as creating novelty where none existed. Of course author cult, like that of God the Father, persists, but in an attenuated form. As a kind of fundamentalism, not open to question.

The author died because: deconstruction. The meaning of the text is not in it, or in an author's intention. Meaning, like justice, communism or the return of the prophet, is always deferred, moved along by reading, never final.
The author died because: psychoanalysis. The author is not consciously in control of creation, is opaque to themself. Desire writes through the writer.

The author died because: marxism. The author is an effect of the invention of copyright, and the fiction of the writer as god-like creator. A notion expanded beyond recognition since the days of Queen Anne.

The author died because: structuralism. The author is an effect of discourse rather than its creator. And an historical one. There weren't always 'authors.' Of what appears on the spine, it's the most recent invention.
The death of the author happened several times in the c20th. I kinda like contemporary writing more if it is intuitively aware of that, and is contemporary with where we are now.
